newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: INSTANT VIEW - NZ Sept qtr retail trade.
newsitem.headline: INSTANT VIEW - NZ Sept qtr retail trade.

text.p: Following are economists' reactions to data on Friday showing a 0.3 percent fall in real, seasonally-adjusted New Zealand retail sales in the September quarter.
Economists were forecasting on average a fall of 0.38 percent for the quarter.
KEVIN SMIT, NATIONAL BANK TREASURY ECONOMIST
"The seasonally adjusted sales before adjustment for price changes were slightly weak but only marginally weaker than we thought...
"The real data was right in line with what we thought and underpins this view that the September quarter won't be a particularly strong quarter in terms of growth.
"I don't think it should make too much difference to financial markets. It was well anticipated.

"It's more a confirmation of the general picture of the economy bumping along the bottom, troughing, rather than giving us any new information about the market being weaker than people generally anticipated."
STEPHEN TOPLIS, DOYLE PATERSON BROWN ECONOMIST

"It is indicative of a general weakening in the economy, and obviously in retail trade in particular, notwithstanding the fact that obviously the numbers are biased downwards by a very weak motor vehicle retailing sector.

"I think if you want to take a pessimistic view of all this, you could actually say retail sales in total have now contracted for two consecutive quarters. That's a reasonably recessionary environment for the total sales, although again it's more driven by the automotive group than anything else.
"On balance it's consistent with what you'd expect to see in an economy that is really being slowed by very tight monetary policy.
"Certainly the Reserve Bank will not be unhappy with these numbers."
